items.text: If the same share of elderly as currently will get access to health care and social care in the future, the supply of these services would have to increase at the same rate as the age groups concerned. (Inpatient care by 70 per cent, home help by 50 per cent and institutionalized care by 80 per cent.)

The expenditures for these services tend to increase faster than the tax revenues from households. This will imply reallocation of resources within the public sector, higher taxes or increased user-fees.

The income standard of those who are retired will decrease as they age relative to the working generations. Younger birth cohorts will get lower relative incomes than older cohorts unless they retire later.
A large share of the very old will get so low incomes that they become poor. This group will not have the means to pay for care.

The baby boom cohorts of the 1940s are relatively wealthy and they will according to our simulations keep their wealth also when they age. This is a potential source to fund increasing care expenditures, but a large share of this wealth is tied up in housing.
We will, however, have a relatively large group of care needing elderly who both have low incomes and very little wealth. This group will not be able to afford higher charges for care.
We should not expect that children and other relatives step in and substitute for public care.
Increased immigration is not very effective in balancing the increased burden of care for our elderly.
Much more effective is an increase in the average retirement age, the ability to maintain high economic growth and good public health.

Our simulations are sensitive to changes in the death rates. Low death rates for “young old” may - depending on the health status of the elderly – result in an increasing number of very old and heavily care dependent persons.

content.text: A model is built to respond to certain scientific problems, or to policy problems. There is no model which can respond to all our problems, now or in the future. The design of a model is determined by its applications. This is true for microsimulation models as well as for other models. In the case of SESIM it was originally designed to analyze the properties of the Swedish student grant and loan system. It was then added to for studies of the properties of the pension system and finally further expanded for a study of the consequences of population ageing. In this gradual expansion of the model more and more submodels have been added to SESIM, such that it today can respond to more questions than its first version could. Is there any limit to the possibilities to add new structures and refine old ones? With unlimited time and resources, perhaps not, but in practice neither time nor resources are unlimited. In policy applications time might be the binding constraint, because policy makers have to take decisions and they need the output from a simulation in time for the decision, while in scientific work resources might be the binding constraint. But the key issue is what properties a model must have to answer a particular policy question. If it is possible to get an intelligent answer from a small model, why use a large and complex one?

The idea behind microsimulation is to model the decisions of those who actually make them, not the make-believe decisions of aggregates of decision makers. In SESIM the unit of analysis is thus the individual and the household. Another important idea is that the model should include the policy instruments that the policy makers actually use, for instance the true eligibility rules for tax deductions and all the details of the tax scales rather than just an average tax rate. SESIM thus includes (almost) all the details of the Swedish personal tax system, social security system and other benefits to the household sector. The model aims at capturing both individual longitudinal trajectories and cross-sectional distributions. Usually, it is of interest to study both the snap-shot of poverty a cross-sectional distribution gives and to understand for how long people stay in poverty. To accomplish this we need both a demographic model that can age and renew the population and dynamic behavioral models which tell us when people take their decisions.

The basic time unit in SESIM is a calendar year. Most simulations are designed to replicate what happens to an individual in a year. One reason for this is that the tax system operates on an annual basis. There are, however, processes which run on a shorter time span. For instance, sickness benefits are given by the day and unemployment compensation by month and day. In these cases we simulate the number of days (months) with benefits within a year, but not when in a year the spells of sickness or unemployment take place. Mostly for practical reasons the model and the simulations have a hierarchical structure. We try to simulate in an order such that decisions which have immediate far-reaching consequences come first in the simulation sequence. This does not necessarily imply that individuals take decisions in this order. In principle one can think of joint decisions, and to some extent it might be possible to model some decisions as joint decisions, but it is hardly practical (or even realistic) to model all decisions in a year as joint. How the model is specified in this respect does not only have implications for the simulations but also for the estimation of the submodels. Models of joint decisions will in general have to be estimated jointly, while models which form a block recursive structure can be estimated recursively.

There are a number of shortcomings of the current version of SESIM. One is that there is no proper labor supply model. There are models for labor force participation, unemployment and retirement, but no model that simulates the number of hours worked, and the only model which has economic incentives built into it is the model for old age retirement. We have run experiments with decreased marginal income tax rates, but the effect of such changes on labor supply and retirement is unrealistically small. SESIM would thus become more useful if it could simulate the annual number of hours worked as a function of the budget set each individual faces. However, the labor supply model cannot be a conventional model of Hausman type. Such a model would give too much mobility in hours worked. We need a model which conditions each individual’s decision on current and possibly past work hours.

Another shortcoming is that there is no functional relationship between health status and death rates. We have experienced that the public expenditures for health care and social care for the elderly depend very much on the death rates. I the life span increases but the age specific health status among the elderly does not improve, we will get an agglomeration of elderly in need of expensive care. It is thus important to understand how health as young and middle-aged influences the health status when people reach a high age, and how changes in health influence the age specific death risks. We would also like to understand better how changes in the economic incentives to work longer will influence the health status of the elderly.

A special problem when modeling the utilization of publicly provided services is that there is no regular market for these services. The fees the users pay are kept artificially low and if there is excess demand access is usually regulated in a queuing system. Changes in utilization will then be determined by political decisions to increase supply. The relations we estimate become a mixture of supply and demand although the models usually are specified as if they were demand models. Simulations are then done using the assumption of unchanged policy.

Still another shortcoming is the absence of market feedback and macroeconomic feedback. SESIM is a model for the household sector, and it does not include any balancing market mechanism. Changes in the macro environment can be fed into the model exogenously but there is no general equilibrium mechanism built into the model. When modeling domestic migration and the demand for housing we considered introducing a price mechanism for owner occupied houses, because the model carries the current migration pattern forward, and it implies that an increasing share of the population will live in the three big cities. This should result in an upward pressure on the real estate prices in the cities, which could counteract the migration flow. Such an increase in real estate prices would also imply a continued shift in wealth from the rural areas to the big cities. For various reasons the introduction of a price mechanism for owner occupied homes was, however, deferred to the future.

As explained in section 3.3 the Ministry of Finance used a macro model to simulate the complete public sector parallel to the household sector of SESIM. The literature also gives a few examples of attempts to integrate a CGE model with a microsimualtion model. These attempts are, however, still experimental. A badly specified CGE model might destroy the microsimulation results. A cautious approach to introduce market feedback is to do it in specific markets as suggested above, and gradually work in the direction of a macro model.

Model building must be based on theory, whether economic theory or theory from another field. Many economic models are of the “ceteris paribus” kind, focusing only on the key phenomenon they were designed to explain, but ignoring much of the complexities that generated data. Such desktop models are not ideal instruments in microsimulation. A model built for simulation should use all the information available at the start of the simulation. As one of the objectives of SESIM is to simulate longitudinal trajectories its models must have a memory. Models which can be estimated from single cross-sections and implicitly assume that new decisions are taken every year independently of past history, will tend to exaggerate mobility. Furthermore, simulation models should be able to simulate the whole distribution of its endogenous variables, not just conditional means. This has implications both for the choice of model structure and in principle also for estimation. For instance, a nonstandard residual structure might hide heterogeneity in behavior; ie the population might consist of several subpopulations that behave differently. A possible solution is then to estimate one model for each subpopulation. An advantage with microsimulation is that heterogeneity of this kind is relatively easy to build into the model.

In SESIM calibration is used to align changes in the simulated demography to the official forecasts of Statistics Sweden (2009), to make the model follow exogenously given paths of certain key variables, such as the rate of unemployment, and to reduce simulation volatility. All these uses have good motivations. Calibration can for instance be a good way to impose alternative exogenous assumptions on the model. But calibration can also be misused if it forces the model into a track it had (almost) never gone into without calibration. Calibration can be viewed as a form of constrained estimation. If the constraints are rejected by the model, enforcing them will in general lead to biased simulations.

Data shortage is usually a severe constraint when building a microsimulation model. SESIM has the advantage of the large and rich micro data of LINDA. A special advantage is that this data source includes exactly the same data used by the tax and social security authorities in computing taxes and benefits. Never-the-less we found it necessary to use complimentary data sources in particular for the health and care models and for geographical mobility. In all cases the unit of analysis – an individual – was the same and many variables were also defined in the same way in all data sources.

Because the simulated values come from a stochastic model estimated from sample data they are uncertain. The stochastic uncertainty originates from three sources: the sample which constitutes the population of SESIM, the estimates of the model parameters and the stochastic structure of the model. The population of SESIM is so large that data uncertainty and simulation uncertainty usually are no problem. Only for small subgroups of the population and in the extreme tails of distributions these sources of uncertainty might become a problem. How much errors in the estimated parameters contribute to total uncertainty is something which still remains to be investigated.

The more we add to a microsimulation model the more difficult it becomes to understand what the model is doing, why it produces the results it does. Depending on the model structure a large model increases the risk that systematic errors from badly specified submodels spread through the entire model. On the other hand, a simulation model like SESIM must capture all important mechanisms that determine our observations. To a degree complexity cannot be avoided. But economic models are still rather small compared to models used in other disciplines, and economists have to learn how to work with large models. How one by using simulation techniques can evaluate the properties of a large model and test it against data.

Are we ready to use large scale microsimulation models for policy advice? I hope the examples I have given in this paper show the potential. If we have the resources needed and are willing to follow rigorous scientific procedures microsimulation is a powerful tool in policy evaluation. It is not one man’s work to build a microsimulation model. Depending on the policy problem one usually needs a team of specialists from different fields. It is also important to have a rather long perspective: When the first version of the model is built who will update it as tax laws and the benefit rules change, who will test it against new data, who will reestimate the behavioral relations and add new submodels, who will evaluate its properties? A successful microsimulation project needs a scientific environment with continuity and resources that most university departments do not provide.
